turn.text: Mr. Olson, may I just detract you from that for a moment and ask the kind of question that Justice Scalia asked of Mr. Abady.

I think you're biting off more than you need to here, and do you at least have, as a second, as an alternate position that even if what you're... what Mr. Abady has argued is right for a Federally created claim, this is an Erie matter, and therefore the Federal court simply can't give awards that you couldn't get in the State court across the street.

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: --I agree with that, and this Court said it best, it seems to me, in the Guaranty trust case, where it said the intent of the Erie decision was to ensure that all cases of Federal court in diversity jurisdiction, the outcome of the litigation in the Federal court should be substantially the same as far as--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I see.
Well, what if it's demonstrable statistically that juries always give higher verdicts than judges would.
Does that mean that the Seventh Amendment becomes a dead letter if a State decides that it is going to allow its judges always to come up with a damage--

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: --It would under no circumstances change, or make the Seventh Amendment a dead letter unless the judges were given the power to substitute their judgment for that of the jury with respect to the amount of damages.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --But they are.
But they are.

As... I mean, the very existence of the Seventh Amendment, if the States don't have it, will lead you to a difference between the amount of money you're going to get in a Federal court that has a jury trial by right and a State court.

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: I don't believe that that's correct, Justice Scalia, based upon what happened in this case.

This is an example of a supervisorial function that will send the case back to a new jury unless the petitioner accepts the amount that the judge said was the maximum amount that the jury could award--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Suppose the State abolishes the jury.

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: --Pardon me?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Suppose the State abolishes the jury and says, we're going to have no more juries.

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: The Seventh Amendment would not tolerate that, and this Court has said--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But we've never held the Seventh Amendment applies to the States.
States can abolish the jury.

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: --I'm talking in terms of--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: --I'm assuming that Justice Scalia was asking about diversity--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Now, would the Federal court have to abolish the jury?

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It couldn't abolish the jury, could it?

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And you get vastly different results... don't you believe you get vastly different results if you have the Federal courts in the State sitting with juries, and the State court sitting without juries?
Where would you bring your lawsuit as a plaintiff?

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: It's entirely possible--
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And do you think that Erie permits that?

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: What the Court has said is that to the extent the legal rules can determine the outcome, the differential in the Federal court should not be different than the State court.
Here we have a substantive decision by New York exercising its legislative function that in actions for recovery of damages there ought to be some limitation, some equality--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Are you arguing that you're not reexamining a question of fact that's tried by a jury--

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: --We are--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --but you are reexamining a mixed question of law and fact?

turn.speaker: theodore_b_olson
turn.label: Mr. Theodore B. Olson
turn.text: --Exactly, and that the grant of a new trial in the first instance is not a reexamination, and Blackstone did not consider that, and he said that in so many words.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Olson.
The case is submitted.
